content.body: othermaciej: FWIW, that *was* me trying to be as civil as possible.
Of course, now we'll probably be treated to another round of thinly-veiled accusations of sexism on alternate content streams.
Sigh.  You just can't win when your opponent is certain that you're evil and wrong.
TabAtkins: just try not to pour fuel on the fire
I recognize that Shelley's tone went somewhat hostile, but a statement like "Also, seriously, chill" seems more likely to escalate the conflict than to cool it off, given the history
Heh, that was meant as an amusing callback to our previous exchange.
I decided to forgo the smilie this time, as that seems to have the opposite effect of what is intended.
I expect Shelley was not amused, and I also think you could have predicted that she would not be amused
I don't mean to be a hardass here, just giving the usual "no fighting in the war room" admonition
inquiring minds want to know: where was the drama?
public-html as always
othermaciej: I am *seriously* not trying to fan any flames with my latest email.  Apologies if anyone does still get mad.  ;_;
now with up to 80% less drama!
just don't make me come back there
You shouldn't have to, unless Shelley gets offended again.  I'm really trying to be as nice as possible here (as opposed to before, when I was being as nice as reasonable).
what exactly are you proposing? I must have skipped past the part of the thread where you suggested something
I asked her to remove the points from her rationale that are solely arguments against @sandbox, rather than against @srcdoc.
oh
well hell, we wouldn't want her to make her proposals more readable, they'd be more likely to pass!
why are you suggesting such a thing
oh wait, i get it, it's reverse psychology! very clever
Because I have an irrational urge to make the process actually work as intended.
you must be new here
ah well. we'll have you turned into a cynic soon enough. no need to rush it i guess.
I'm a cynical idealist.  Why isn't this good enough?
Anyway, out for the night.
later
Hixie, brainstorming about timed text markup formats.  What were the extensions you were thinking of for timestamps and stage directions in <dialog>?
Hixie: about http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9472 (deal with broken links in dynamic author view of spec by prompting users to choose to switch to full view)
did you deploy a change for that already?
anyone know if Arabic Taškīl, Hebrew Niqqud, or other non-CJK languages would use ruby for marking up phonetic annotations or diacritics?
boblet: Richard Ishida would know
I seem to remember some examples in ruby supplementary docs of non-Chinese/Japanese languages that had ruby annotations
but I dunno remember where
MikeSmith: you’ll be thinking of the dodgy abbreviation WWW and expiry date in Ruby Annotation I bet
yeah I need to ping Richard, he’d definitely know. will email him
abbr as ruby: http://www.w3.org/TR/ruby/#simple-ruby1
ruby as formatting hack: http://www.w3.org/TR/ruby/#complex
MikeSmith: apart from that I’ve only found Chinese & Japanese examples. I can’t even determine if Korean use hangul ruby with hanzi or not
boblet: I have never seen any examples of hanzi with ruby
but I don't encounter a lot of Korean text anyway

MikeSmith: me neither, so wondering if they just don’t do it. South Korea is basically moving to all hangul, but I think they still use about 1000 hanzi. North Korea supposedly completely stopped teaching them in like the 60s but then reintroduced them due to Chinese
don’t know any Koreans I can ask :(
they still use a lot of hanzi in Korean, from what I have seen while visiting there
e.g., many buildings have names written in hanzi and such
and 20-years-olds or so still know many kanji
I think they still teach them in high school
but I suspect in Korean the logograms all have only a single reading
so the reading is unambiguous, and they wouldn't need ruby for showing phonetic readings
I think
well, assuming you know how to read them ;-) wonder if they have hanzi/hangul/romanisation on eg train signs. don’t remember
boblet: what are you writing that article on?
paul_irish: HTML5 ruby, for HTML5Doctors
ruby! sweeet
it’s killing me >_<
ruby and rt are so sexy
emoticon fail that should be the Japanese ＞＿＜ emoji
paul_irish: like I said, i18n and a11y are bad enough on their own. combining them
ouch
http://webkit.org/blog/1091/more-web-inspector-updates/
cool stuff
boblet: can you think of a Japanese equivalent of "Eeny, meeny, miny, moe"?
oh
found it
eigiro to the rescue
http://eow.alc.co.jp/Eeny/UTF-8/?ref=sa
hmm, it's only an explanation
doesn't say what equivalent if any there is
doesn't everyone just do junken?
oh nevermind, you mean for selecting somethign ;>
wirepair: yeah, for picking somebody to be "it"
mike, just asked a friend they do the same thing 'do re ni shi yo u ka na'
ten no ka mi sa ma
etc
so what is in that alc description is right hehe
intersting
I guess I can ask my daughter too
for an authoritative
viewpoint
since she must use something when playing kakurembo etc.
i just found out they do the same thing with flower petals
he seemed really surprisd we do it too ;>
surprised rather
MikeSmith: yes
MikeSmith: (re the links in author mode thing)
Hixie: what's the expected behavior?
does it pop up a prompt?
yeah
Ok
I'll have to try again
I tried in Webkit and Minefield and it didn't seem to work
hm
what were you trying?
I'm trying clicking on the links in the IDLs
on what page?
it only seems to work when loading the page with a broken fragment, not loading then clicking a broken link
make sure the browser you are using supports the 'hashchange' event
ok, works fine for me in chrome
Hixie: I got a comment in the public-html-ig-jp which asks whether <figcaption> can have flow content inside: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-ig-jp/2010Apr/0010.html
Content model:
Phrasing content.
so no.
I guess so. Then the example in http://www.whatwg.org/html5#table-descriptions (labbeled "Next to the table, in a figure's figcaption") is wrong :)
oh, good point
i'll file a bug, thanks
wait what, didn't we change the content model to flow before?
when it was called <legend>
it probably changed back when i made it <dt>
it should allow flow, since there are use cases for it (same as <caption>)
already filed the bug
ok, first i thought you wanted to change the example
ah, no, sorry for the confusion
was about to reply that the example was wrong. phew.
Hixie: why does send() return a boolean? it seems the browser could return true but the sending will still fail (e.g. because the server has closed the connection before the data is actually sent)
Hixie: a more reliable check would involve looking at wasClean and bufferedAmount, and then the return value of send() seems useless
the return value is just to help you if you're sending data on a timeout, i think
it's a coarse and blunt instrument
what does help with?
come again?
i mean, why do we have a boolean return value at all? what problem does it solve?
someone asked for it at some point
it seemed harmless to provide
i forget the details
fixed figcaption to be flow
i am so not looking forward to working out how Selection.modify() works
Hixie: OK, I see (about the link pop-up feature)
thanks
np
if you know how to make it work in other browsers let me know
should work at least in chrome and ie
what browsers suppor the hashchange event? IE and CHrome?
kk
Hixie: you could listen for click events
Hixie: although personally i'd just wait for browsers to implement hashchange :)
yeah
this gives other browser projects some good incentive to implement it
MikeSmith: so how was the tv show? did you watch it?
myakura: it's actually on tonight
MikeSmith: d'oh. I thought it was 14th.
i actually thought everyone did hashchange when i implemented it, i woulda checked otherwise :-)
ben_alman wrote a pretty good program for detecting hash changes.
May not be at all what you're talking about or looking for, but just in case http://benalman.com/projects/jquery-bbq-plugin/
http://yfrog.com/06h39aj
w00t http://www.apple.com/euro/itunes/charts/apps/top10appstorefree.html
yea that's pretty awesome for Opera.
zcorpan: something wrong with Australia :-)
hsivonen: yeah, what's up there
I dunno, they were Opera earlier today.
They love their birds, I guess.
tweeted
I saw Opera on there the other day, it was so freaking fast and snappy.
or twitted or ...
neat!
though it makes me want to download Bird Strike
Don't do it!  It's #2 in the US.
Hixie: I recommend mixing around your browser usage now and then :p
your hashchange assumption is a clear sign that you are secretly a dedicated IE user/fanboy
isn't everybody an ie fanboy
i wonder if ie copes with complete.html
I just got a great error message from my IMAP server via mutt : "Too many consecutive protocol violations."
Hixie, othermaciej - I'm thinking of setting up a mailbot that automatically raises bugzilla bugs for all new messages posted to public-html-comments
MikeSmith: hmmm
where new = does not have an In-reply-to or References header
othermaciej: bad idea?
you're gonna have to hire someone else to help me with dealing with the noise if you do that
I'm thinking about whether typical emails to that list make for a good bug
hmm, OK
I think a lot of the emails there have one of the following properties:
- really an idea for discussion, not an actionable problem report
- include large numbers of potentially separate issues
there have also been comments against different specs
ok
point taken
I don't know if I have seen a single one that would meet all our criteria for good info to put in a bug report
clearly some human needs to be in the decision pipe
maybe an on-demand version of this tool would be useful
where it's easy for some trusted set of people to convert a public-html-comments email into a bug
yeah
that's a better approah
*way
just thinking about how we handle comments on that list after we start LC
lots of actual discussion there too, at least in the past month :-/
I think our Last Call statement needs to indicate that the way to give a Last Call comment and get a response is to file a bug
I would be very happy with that
would make all our lives a lot easier
Paul Cotton seemed to indicate that this was seen as acceptable in the past for other WGs
yeah
so let's do that
make it the responsibility of the commenter to actually raise the bug themselves
now that I say that, that's the only way the really makes sense anyway
raising bugs on behalf of somebody else is not a good idea
will public-html-comments be closed down with all comments directed to bugzilla?
what does tl;dr mean in email context?
is it like ignored and deleted or some such?
(see hybi for an example)
in general it means "too long; didn't read", but responding to an email on a standards list that way is kind of ridiculous
aah, what an asshole

hmm, http://www.w3.org/XML/2010/04/xml-model/ .. "This document allows schemas using any schema definition language to be associated with an XML document by including one or more processing instructions with a target of xml-model in the document's prolog"
annevk: careful, that dude was 'nominated one of the "50 most influential people in IP" by Managing Intellectual Property magazine'
so you better give him some due respect
I wonder if that means he was nominated, but lost
heh
waves to annevk. welcome back :)
"This specification is complementary technology which can be used when it is necessary to store ad-hoc schema associations directly inside XML document."
thanks myakura! nice to be back :)
is it a good idea to subscribe to hybi?
subscribes
zcorpan: you still in the XML Core WG
I think I'll file an editorial bug saying that they wrote "necessary" in the sentence above, when what they actually mean is "convenient"
MikeSmith: yes
zcorpan: please beat some sense into those guys
zcorpan, no, but I guess you should
zcorpan: it may be a good idea only in the sense that subscribing to public-html is a good idea
I wonder what rock the hybi folks have been living under not to have seen code written very, very badly by Web authors
hsivonen: you don't have to look at content to serve it I guess...
http://twitter.com/benschwarz/statuses/12193163314 -- must have been inevitable that tweets like this would happen
annevk: I don't understand what he is responding to there
or what his question means...
hi
othermaciej, yeah, not really sure either, but the implication seems to be that "those people" were also responsible for HTML4
I think he's claiming that the people on the WHATWG list prevented progress in HTML after  HTML4
which is a very interesting reading of history
right

othermaciej: "maybe an on-demand version of this tool would be useful" "where it's easy for some trusted set of people to convert a public-html-comments email into a bug" - how would the tool be more useful than simply copying-and-pasting into a bug report?
Philip`: fewer mouse movements?
files bugs on html5test
were there other things wrong other than the codecs?
he's been really active in development of the new version.. lots of fixes and changes have already went in
even moved some of the sections so people wouldnt miscontrue that they were part of html5..
hmm i should have looked at trunk source instead of deployed source
zcorpan: and here's his thoughts on including codecs.. http://rakaz.nl/2010/03/the-html5-test.html#comment-1603
"IE9 video tag should follow standard object fallback principals if this video is any indication:
http://live.visitmix.com/MIX10/Sessions/CL27" -- http://www.cssquirrel.com/2010/03/22/comic-update-ie-nine-means-business/#comment-31899
srsly? if that's true, microsoft are clearly incapable of implementing the spec
"if the video element fails for any reason, it'll fallback to teh contents inside" he says in the video
hrmm
refuses to watch videos of talks, but will ping a friend over at MS for confirmation about what's happening there.
I also hate videos of talks.
Way too hard to skim.
And audio.
Yus.  Both are my primary difficulties with the format.  Gimme a transcript, much easier to use.
Score another point for a11y's unintended positive effects!
reflects on Chrome's decision to strip "http://" from the beginning of URLs in UI
Seems to make sense.
I don't really notice it.
That hasn't made it to stable yet.  I suppose I should follow dev channel.  What's the easiest way to put myself on such?
Google "Chrome dev channel" and follow the links?
I've actually found it kind of annoying.
It's a little too crashy/unstable.
I'd switch to the beta channel if I weren't too lazy.
kk
You can switch to it easily, but switching back is trickier, I think.
Not sure how well it works.
Ah, nm, doesn't look like they have beta releases for linux?
I guess I can run it on my W7 box.
They only have beta and dev for Linux, last I checked.
No stable.
(beta != dev, of course)
Yeah, dev is weekly pushes, beta is monthly, stable is quarterly.
Something like that.
I don't think that's precise, though.
That's what I heard yesterday when one of our engineers asked what the update schedule was, at least.
Why do Google people call programmers "engineers"?
Dunno.
Everyone at Google does it consistently, but like no one else does.
That's just our term for some reason.  We're all hired as "software engineers".
Well, that's a very common term in bureaucrat-speak, but in most places normal people don't use it.
Shrug.
It sounds vaguely grandiose for some reason.  Not sure why, since it's not like actual engineering is particularly harder or more prestigious or better-paying than software development.
Maybe because it implies a kind of exactness and certainty that doesn't really exist in software.
I suppose it was considered the most appropriate term that still covered all the different things that we hire people for, not all of which is programming.
(Excluding non-technical things like advertising or sales or HR, obviously.)
Maybe that's a flaw in the entire concept of job titles, then.  I once heard (never checked) that the credits for Valve games mostly don't have titles.  Just a long undifferentiated list of people.
Because apparently they each do whatever they're interested in and good at doing.
Or something.
We don't really *have* job titles, except as a very generic slotting mechanism, like I said.  Every single technical hire at Google is a "software engineer".  Nothing more, nothing less.
Interesting.
http://www.mobygames.com/game/windows/half-life-2/credits
AryehGregor: I thhink it's standard practice elsewhere, too, not just at Google to treat "programmer" as a dirty word and call people software developers or software engineers
Then we just get picked up by a particular team, and identify ourselves that way.  We're encourage to move around between teams, though.
Undifferentiated except for voices, face usage, and legal.
hsivonen, "developers" I'm used to, "engineers" strikes me as a bit weird.
Anyway, whatever.
Developers is somewhat inaccurate for some people, though!  I'm not a developer right now, frex.
Whereas we're all engineering software to some degree.
. . . kind of.
votes that everyone's job title should be "Employee".
Can I change my name to my SSN, too?
"SharedWorker"
i wanna be Señor Employee
As we live in Amurrica, I will make it a point to call you *Mr.* Employee, miketaylr.
TabAtkins, I'm pretty sure a judge wouldn't approve that.
(the name change)
has always lived in primarily Hispanic areas anyway.
same.
Me too, I guess.
Although I don't think of it that way, since among neighborhood people I practically only interact with the Jews.
Although that's because I don't leave the house except when I have to go pray, to be fair.
hmm, now i'm in an predominantly arab, irish, and norwegian 'hood tho
If it weren't for that, I'd spend weeks at a time without leaving my house, at least when I don't have school.
Mountain View has a lot more asian varieties mixed in, but I'm still in a Hispanic area of town.  Which a huge plus, because good hole-in-the-wall taquerias OMNOMNOMNOM
mmmm
that's #1 on my list when i head out for the SF jQuery conf.
burros
When's the jQuery conf?
next weekend the 24th 25th
feel free to insert between 1 and 3 commas in that
I choose a comma and "and"
Any of you guys doing a dinner some night?
paul_irish would be the guy to ask, being the insider
they might be doing dinner onsite at the conf? dunno
Yeah, I'll wait for him to come around and ask then.
will be at the SFBA jQuery conf too
word up
i should like, write my talk
TabAtkins: sunday night we'll probably pull some folks together. i'll keep you in the loop (& hober too)
Awesome.  I'd like to meet you guys ftf.
Whoa: http://to./
totally
A TLD URL shortener.
You can only beat that if someone convinces ICANN to approve a one-letter TLD.  :P
Good PR on Tonga's part?
I'm not sure how that works.  It looks like the tld is the empty string.
And the server name is just "to"
Trailing dots in domain names are usually ignored.
I'm not sure why it's required here.
Observe: http://google.com./
The trailing dot is always present in the actual DNS request, I think.  If you omit the dot, then the domain name is relative or something.
I dunno, don't remember the details.
Anyway, that's the .to TLD.
Ok.
running a TLD is expensive. is there money in shorteners?
Does HTML5 specify that we should ignore stylesheet <link>s which don't appear in the document's <head>?  I can't find language one way or another.
twitter doesnt autolink the to./ shortened url's sadly. otherwise its the shortest shortener (though very close to  tinyarro.ws)
Depends.  If you think people will abide by you showing a page while redirecting, you can do ads.  Otherwise, you can sell usage info.
jlebar: I don't believe it requires ignoring them - I think it requires implementations to respect them
jlebar: however, it's nonconforming for content to have a stylesheet <link> outside the <head> section
othermaciej, Thanks.
paul_irish, miketaylr, TabAtkins: sounds good to me.
TabAtkins: let me know if MS says anything about video
hober: yt?

i find it amusing that some of the people who are most adament that we shouldn't violate the Atom spec's authoring requirements are the same people who argued that one option for HTML was to drop all authoring requirements
isn't that basically just Sam? (I don't think Julian ever suggested "drop all authoring requirements")
keeps getting secret invites to beta tests for font things for some reason.
Slightly related: FF's 3.6's font rendering on linux is occasionally extremely ugly.  It's like, every once in a while, for no reason, they lose the ability to do sub-pixel stuff.
So letters either gain odd extra-pixel spaces between them, or randomly switch between having 1 or 2px wide verticals, etc.
TabAtkins: ah you got that too? i would talk to you about it, but a checkbox i click seems to indicate that would be a faux pas..
i'd dying for directwrite support to land in FF

i give up on this atom thread. Neither Julian nor Sam are listening to a word I'm saying, both just keep repeating the same argument over and over despite my having explained why both their arguments are inapplicable.
I'm not quite sure about Julian (he posts too much in that thread, so I've just sort of skimmed his arguments) but I think Sam is listening to you, but disagreeing in a different direction.
I think you can interpret his words as agreeing with you on "there's a bug in the Atom spec".  He'd probably say differently, but I believe the net effect of what he's saying is the same.
Hixie: here
hober: i replied to your mail
TabAtkins: he keeps asking me to "test to see what happens when the IDs change" despite the fact that I'm not disagreeing with him on what happens if hte IDs change
I think all Sam's trying to say with that is "feeds with shitty entry IDs and/or updated datetimes suck." Which, obviously, everyone knows so I don't know why he's banging on about that bit
He's banging on about it because the HTML5 Atome extraction algo will, I think, generate shitty entry IDs (or no entry IDs?  Similar problems exist.).
HTML5 doesn't require you to preserve the entry ID if you generate the feed multiple times
(or rather, it is a SHOULD rather than a MUST)
but it's not clear how much of that requirement is needed to avoid aggregators breaking
we could change it to "MUST if possible" i guess
Yeah, I see it now.
I suspect just requiring that the identical document sent through the same converter to generate identical atom:ids is both feasible and would mostly solve that particular problem
Nod to othermaciej.
"MUST if possible" means "SHOULD"!
i know
that's why i wrote SHOULD
but apparently that's not good enough for julian and sam
Hixie: use "OUGHT TO" ( ref: http://edward.oconnor.cx/2006/02/more-rfc-2119-humor )
I don't really understand the scope of the Atom spec's MUST
It seems pretty easy to figure out how to generate a guurl from the article address and content.
when Julian has explained what he thinks it does and doesn't require, it sounds like he's making stuff up to suit his preferences rather than interpreting the Atom spec
It is somewhat more difficult to generate one if the article changes between runs.
Which I think they raised as a problem with it.
yeah, the only truly sound way to deal with "article changes between runs" is to require the HTML document to have unique IDs embedded
othermaciej: FWIW, I thought your point re: "why the double standard between text->atom and html->atom" was spot-on
hober: I still don't feel like he gave a straight answer
othermaciej: Right.  So I think I'm fine with that.  Changing the SHOULD to a MUST would still allow the ids to be different if the content changes between runs (it wont' be the "same input").
but I also don't understand the double standard between "two runs of same converter" and "runs of different converters"
TabAtkins: it's not clear to me if Julian or Sam would be fine with that, or whether they would see that as violating the Atom spec (a possibly separate question)
othermaciej: That one, at least, is similar to the distinction between "run on the same input" versus "run on similar input".
the problem is that the Atom requirement just doesn't make sense when starting from non-Atom input
Right.
it's totally plausible to apply to systems that are already operating in Atom
exactly
Unless the content happens to also embed an appropriate guid.
but it's unimplementable if your input doesn't already have globally unique IDs embedded
yup
that's exactly the line of thought i went through when i wrote this stuff
hence the should
So, yeah, bug in the Atom spec.  Change our spec to a MUST, and possibly explicitly call out the failing.
it *is* implementable for the special case of "same converter and identical content"
It won't be a violation of our MUST if UAs generate new ids for altered content.
one thing that's worth considering is whether we are interested in having a solution that outputs almost-valid atom that can be hand fixed to valid atom, or if we think the output must be valid atom
The latter.  Not much point in an automatic extraction algorithm if you still have to hand-edit the result.
Since the producer won't be the one doing the extracting, the consumer will.
Hixie: my first choice is that the algorithm do what it's doing now. html -> atom tools can (and should) help their users improve their HTML so that the results are valid
my second choice, if the output must be valid Atom, is to drop entries that we can't come up with IDs from. that way the entries that do end up in the feed don't annoy the crap out of subscribers
hober: For your first choice, does that resolve to the former or latter option in hixie's question?
It sounds like the latter, unless you're seriously suggesting that feed readers should ask their users to correct the HTML of feed producers.
TabAtkins: the former, though I wouldn't suggest that people hand-edit the atom
Who is supposed to edit the Atom, then?  At what point in the chain does it go from almost-valid to valid?
I don't expect anybody to edit the Atom.
I've got a site, and I decide to use an html2atom tool to make a feed from it
I go to the tool, paste in my URL, and the result page is something like
Then it never becomes valid, and you *can't* be agreeing with Hixie's former option.
(Because that option, be definition, requires someone to edit the Atom at some point to make it valid.)
"here's a url to an atom feed for your page. it doesn't look like it's valid; here are some ways you could improve your site so that your feed is more useful. have a nice day"
or "here's a url... it's valid, congrats! here's a pat on the head"
That's not the same use-case as "consume an HTML page as Atom".  That's an HTML->Atom validator.
no, it's a converter, that's providing lint-tool-esque advice when used
the feed consumers just get the url to the (possibly invalid) atom feed
It's allowed to flag things that aren't right.  An actual conversion algo, though, either needs to output something valid, or we need to define exactly who turns it valid.
it's the person feeding the site itno the converter that sees the lint/validation advice
Okay, such a tool could work equally by only producing a valid feed, but also flagging things that it's skipped for invalidity.
sure
hence my compromise proposal to julian
Then let's make sure that the algo just produces a valid feed.
And let the market help people make their feeds better.
sounds good to me
For any folks working on Microdata in here, it would be nice if I could put itemprop="fn org logo" on an with an alt.
Hixie: ^^^ There really should be a way to get @alt in the property value.  Automatically, preferably.

JonathanNeal: You wouldn't be able to put it on the directly, anyway - that just grabs the @src instead. But you *should* be able to put in on a or

or whatnot wrapping the .
Yea that works too :)
TabAtkins: seems lame to add a span just to emit another property
I think in microformats you can place it on the itself.
othermaciej: Shrug. Grabbing the @src of an is useful.
pokes you for keeping up with the Jones'.
TabAtkins: I agree - and as just mentioned, grabbing the alt is also useful
And so it should continue to be easy to do so.  Using a wrapper is the obvious way to grab the alt without interfering with that.
I think it would be a design flaw if you had to add a superfluous DOM element just to emit both
although I do not have another design to propose
You have to add wrappers for a lot of things in Microdata, if your data is part of prose.

Though, with JonathanNeal's use-case, the will commonly already have a wrapper

to use.
You either have to add wrapper, or add another level of indirection to specify where the property value comes from.  The former seems a lot better to me, in this context.\
(If you asked me the same question in a CSS context, I'd say the opposite, because we love indirection.)
CSS WG must have a bunch of computer scientists in it
Yes.
when designing microdata i thought long and hard about how to get to output one property for src="" and one for alt="" and i ended up deciding that was the mistake RDFa had made
well, one of several, i guess
Yeah, I don't think it should do it magically. But I think that should output foo:"qux", bar:"baz".
Agreed that trying to stack the two together is a mistake in RDFa.

Essentially just, whenever a property is using the text content of an element for its value, should substitute in its @alt value. That's the whole point of @alt, after all - to be a textual equivalent of the image.
TabAtkins: in current Microdata, what would emit?
(note lack of itemprop on the img itself)
foo:""
Because @alt isn't part of the element's textContent.
would you propose changing what the markup I cited emits, or only in the case where the img element has an itemprop?
and what if there is more than just the element inside the span?
additional side note: is there a way to get the contents of a "title" attribute into a Microdata property?
I would propose changing what the markup you cited emits.  It should emit foo:"qux".
those are the two cases I can think of where useful text is likely to be an attribute value instead of text content

Microdata currently defines that case as being the value of textContent.  This is a property exposed by whatever DOM implementation you're using.  We'd define a new property for DOM implementations to support that does "smart" text content.
If you're not relying on an external parser to create and handle the DOM, then adding "smart" text content handling is *definitely* not a "doubling or tripling" of your code size.
you'd be surprised
textContent is implementable in about 3 lines
what we're talking about here basically means implementing an HTML renderer for plain text
that's 100+ lines
maybe far more
A "renderer" that handles, what, four cases total?  Plain text, <q> text, bidi text, and @alt.
All I want is alt :)
If you're starting from a SAX parser or something, it's definitely not 100+ lines unless you really, really suck somehow.
there's far more to HTML than just the cases I mentioned
how to best benchmark how much time browser spends rematching css on dom tree when i change the dom tree using js?

Let's see... I can see the possibility that you might want to do <sub> and <sup>, but I don't think there's an accept way to render them in plaintext.  You could *maybe* argue that <em> and <strong> deserve special formatting, but I can reasonably argue against it, I think.  I believe that's about it.
Everything else is sufficient as plain text for any purpose that Microdata might need.
i am highly skeptical
and again, i really don't think the use cases need this
I think that @alt is the highest-priority one.
If you're rolling your own DOM, then just where you loop through the nodes and check if they're text nodes, also check if they're element nodes with the name "img".
That is 2 lines (possibly more depending on your code formatting guidelines).
You're already having to check if a node is an element node, to know if you have to recurse into it to search for more text nodes.
All I want is alt :)
So I challenge your statement that this would greatly increase the implementation cost.  The increase is so minor as to be trivial.
